Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: In Search of a Molecular Switch Between the Native SgAP Hydrolase Activity and the Native Glutaminyl Cyclase Activity in a Homologous Enzyme

POR.DRECONTENT:
Justin P. Moses

Ph.D Candidate

Dr. Li-June Ming, Advisor

University of South Florida

Department of Chemistry

4202 E. Fowler Ave.

Tampa FL, 33620

NSFID 000553163

Proposal   6986490

EAPSI 2010 Taiwan

 

While it is common for an enzyme to recognize and catalyze the conversion of several similar substrates, the same cannot be said for one enzyme to utilize more than one distinct catalytic mechanism on considerably different substrates. Streptomyces griseus amino peptidase (SgAP) is one such enzyme that is known as being catalytically promiscuous upon the binding of various metals. The nature of the enzyme makes it ideal to study how metals function within the enzyme framework for the purposes of modeling and how accidental chemistries serve as stepping stones in protein evolution.

Glutaminyl cyclase (QC) or other enzymes displaying QC activity have been found in a wide range of animal, and plant sources. Human QC has been implicated in amyloid formation inside of the brain due to its ability to cyclize glutamate into pyroglutamate an activity that could contribute to the development of Alzheimer’s disease. The role in essential post-translational modification of proteins within the cell has been linked to osteoporosis in women in some part to processing estrogen. The native form retains a single zinc ion in the active site, and requires no other co-factors for activity. Bioinformatic studies predicted some homology with aminopeptidases and the recently solved crystal structure shows significant identity with the catalytically promiscuous active site found in SgAP. Mutation of SgAP to mimic QC activity may increase the  understanding of protein engineering, enzyme modeling, drug design, and protein evolution.

This research was intended to clone SgAP and QC into a system that would allow easy modification and amplification of these two enzymes for research purposes as described. The process used to clone enzymes into appropriate systems is well known, however working through pivotal hang-ups often takes tedious troubleshooting. In this case, SgAP was successfully cloned, however QC was not. More troubleshooting is necessary to determine why the clone was unsuccessful and to fully express SgAP for investigation.

Because this particular field of study is not something that our lab was very familiar with, the NSF EAPSI program facilitated travel to the host lab of Dr. Tung-Kung Wu at National Chiao Tung University in Taiwan. Here, new techniques were introduced and training was administered to allow this of project to proceed.

            While this particular set of work by itself does not offer any impact to the field, the research resulting from the information learned has potential to change the way researchers view various enzymes in the brain. Too often an enzyme is studied with the concept that it retains a single function that may have multiple impacts. Shifting the focus to multiple functions with multiple impacts could have significant ramifications on the design of various therapies and drugs for a number of diseases
